skill.name: docstring
skill.description: Write docstrings for PyTorch functions and methods following PyTorch conventions. Use when writing or updating docstrings in PyTorch code.
skill.summary: Write docstrings for PyTorch functions and methods following PyTorch conventions. Use when writing o...
skill.author: pytorch

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only a SKILL.md file with markdown guidelines. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or environment variable reads. The skill provides only documentation and prompting guidance for writing PyTorch docstrings.

content.value_statement: Writing consistent, professional docstrings for PyTorch functions requires following specific conventions. This skill provides detailed guidelines for generating properly formatted docstrings using Sphinx/reStructuredText, mathematical notation, and cross-references.
actual_capabilities: Generate docstrings with function signatures in PyTorch format
Format mathematical formulas using LaTeX notation for tensor shapes
Create Args, Returns, Keyword args, and Examples sections
Use warning and note directives for important caveats
Handle C-bound functions with add_docstr patterns
limitations: Skill is specific to PyTorch conventions only
Does not generate docstrings for other frameworks or general Python
Does not validate or test generated docstrings
Does not access external documentation sources

use_cases.title: Document new functions
use_cases.description: Generate properly formatted docstrings for new PyTorch functions following project conventions.

use_cases.title: Update existing documentation
use_cases.description: Maintain consistency when adding or modifying docstrings in PyTorch codebase.

use_cases.title: Contribute to PyTorch
use_cases.description: Write documentation that matches PyTorch standards for pull requests.

prompt_templates.title: Basic docstring
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a docstring for a function called torch.my_function that takes input tensor and an optional beta parameter.

prompt_templates.title: Complete docstring
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complete docstring for a convolution function with Args, Returns, Examples, and mathematical formulas.

prompt_templates.title: C-bound function
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a docstring using add_docstr for a C-bound function torch.my_conv with stride and padding parameters.

prompt_templates.title: In-place operation
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an in-place variant docstring for abs_ that references the original Tensor.abs method.

output_examples.input: Write a docstring for a function called gumbel_softmax that takes logits, tau, hard, eps, and dim parameters.
output: ‚Ä¢ Function signature on first line with all parameters and types
‚Ä¢ Args section documenting each parameter with types
‚Ä¢ Returns section with Tensor type and description
‚Ä¢ Examples section with Python code blocks
‚Ä¢ Note and warning blocks for important caveats

best_practices: Always use raw strings (r"""") to avoid issues with LaTeX backslashes
Include function signature on the first line with all parameters and return type
Add cross-references using :class:, :func:, and :meth: Sphinx roles
Include at least one example in the Examples section when possible
anti_patterns: Using regular strings instead of raw strings for docstrings
Omitting parameter types or default values in documentation
Forgetting to use double backticks for inline code values
Missing cross-references to related PyTorch classes and functions

faq.question: What format does this skill use for PyTorch docstrings?
faq.answer: The skill follows Sphinx/reStructuredText (reST) format with specific PyTorch conventions for docstrings.

faq.question: Does this skill support other Python libraries besides PyTorch?
faq.answer: No, this skill is specifically designed for PyTorch documentation conventions only.

faq.question: How are mathematical formulas formatted in the docstrings?
faq.answer: Mathematical formulas use Sphinx math directives (.. math::) for block formulas and :math: for inline math with LaTeX notation.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill only provides documentation guidelines. It does not read files, make network calls, or store any data.

faq.question: Why are raw strings (r""") required for PyTorch docstrings?
faq.answer: Raw strings prevent backslash escape processing, which is essential for LaTeX mathematical notation and math directives in documentation.

faq.question: How does this compare to auto-docstring tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides PyTorch-specific conventions rather than generic auto-generation. It ensures documentation follows project standards exactly.
